text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm web pumpkin spice snickerdoodles
that's right instead of adding pumpkin
spice to things for no apparent reason
you know like coffee and beer we're
going to add it to something where it
actually makes sense like the always
popular cinnamon sugar cookie known as
the snickerdoodle and of course I'm
mostly kidding about the coffee and the
beer if you want to ruin those things by
adding pumpkin spice Who am I to judge
but here I don't think we're going to
have any controversy at all
since I believe these spices take an
already great cookie and make it even
better so with that let's go ahead and
get started with our dry ingredients
which as usual is going to start with
some all-purpose flour to which we will
add some salt as well as some baking
soda which we will follow by a spoon of
cream of tartar and I'm going to talk
about this on the blog post but when you
use baking soda and cream of tartar
you've basically made your own baking
powder and why we would even want to do
that I'll try to explain in the blog
post but in the meantime let's continue
on with our spices which will of course
include cinnamon which as you may know
is your signature snickerdoodle spice so
we'll do some cinnamon followed by the
rest of our pumpkin spice which includes
some ground ginger some clove some
allspice and then last but not least
some freshly grated nutmeg which I took
the liberty of freshly grated ahead of
time and then what we'll do once we have
all that together is take a whisk and
we'll give that a mix for a minute or
two to thoroughly combine those
ingredients sure if your grandma's
watching and you want to sift this
instead so she feels like her advice is
still relevant go ahead but for all
practical purposes this really does
accomplish the same thing and then what
we'll do once that's combined to set
that aside and move on to the wet
ingredients and by wet I mostly mean
buttery so let's start with one stick of
unsalted room-temperature butter to
which we're going to add some white
sugar as well as some light brown sugar
and then what we're going to need to do
is take the back of a spatula or spoon
and somehow cream that room-temperature
butter and sugar together and of course
this will be a lot easier if we use an
electric mixer but whenever possible
especially for cookie recipes I prefer
to do it by hand if possible
I've always felt the cookies should not
be too easy to make otherwise we'd make
them
often plus we're burning a few extra
calories and we won't have to clean our
mixer and fair warning when you first
start mashing this together
it's going to be a little difficult a
little bit frustrating and borderline
discouraging but don't worry as long as
your butter was room-temperature
eventually we'll all start to smear
together and if you keep at it after
just a minute or two it should cream
together nicely and you should end up
with something looks pretty close to
this and then what we'll do once at set
is add the rest of the wet ingredients
which will include a nice splash of pure
vanilla extract remember real cooks
never use fake extracts and then we'll
also go ahead and crack in one large egg
at which point we will take our spatula
and mix this thoroughly and if you watch
me make cookies before you probably know
I start with the spatula and then get
frustrated it's not working well and
then switch to the whisk but then all
the batter gets stuck on the inside of
the whisk so I switch back to the
spatula so this time I decide to save an
entire step and I just stubbornly stuck
with a spatula throughout the entire
mixing process and while it probably did
take me an extra minute it eventually
worked and I was able to get all those
ingredients combined and once that's
been accomplished our last step here
will be to pour our dry ingredients into
this bowl and continue mixing with the
spatula until just combined and by just
combined I mean just mix it until the
flour disappears and there are some
cookie dough recipes where over mixing
could be a problem but this really isn't
one of them so unless you continue
mixing long after the flours disappeared
you shouldn't have any problem in fact
the most challenging part about this
last step is simply keeping the flour in
the bowl as you're mixing it it tends to
want to escape but don't let it just
sort of carefully work that over with
the spatula until like I said our dry
mixture has just been incorporated at
which point we will stop because our
pumpkin spice snickerdoodle dough is
done oh yeah try saying that three times
fast snickerdoodle dough is done I can
barely say it one time slow but anyway
once our snickerdoodle dough is done we
have a decision to make we can cook this
right away which I'm guessing most of my
audience will do I mean come on
willpower is not your strong suit but
what I am recommending is that we wrap
this up and pop in the fridge and chill
it before we try to use it like I said
you can use it if you have to but in
general cookie dough's are much easier
to work with
they're cold and that butter is firm
back up so I did wrap mine up and pop it
in the fridge for about an hour and what
I think we should do while we're waiting
is mix up our cinnamon and sugar mixture
which not surprisingly is made by
stirring some cinnamon into sugar and
what we'll use this for is to coat our
dough balls in before we bake them and
yes of course if you want you could
double down on your pumpkin spice and
add some more of that to this mixture
but anyway we'll go ahead and stir some
cinnamon and sugar together and then
we'll just set that aside and wait until
our dough is chilled which mine is so
we'll go ahead and pull that out of the
fridge and I'll go ahead and unwrap that
and portion it using one of these sorbet
scoops which slightly rounded gives me
exactly two tablespoons which for me is
the perfect size and once we scoop our
dough we'll transfer that into our sugar
mixture and kind of roll it around to
make sure it's coated and that is pretty
much it
once coated we'll roll that into a
smooth ball and transfer that onto a
Silpat lined baking sheet and then I do
like to press them down just a little
and that's mostly so they don't roll out
of position when I transfer them in the
oven but I also think it makes them come
out a little thinner and as you can see
I'm giving those a lot of space I'm just
going to go with eight to a pan and then
what we'll do once those are panned up
is transfer those into the center of a
350 degree oven for about 10 to 12
minutes or until they look like this
so of course exact cooking time is going
to depend on how crispy /qu euy your
cookies but for me about 11 minutes was
perfect and then what I like to do is
let these sit on the baking sheet for
about 5 minutes before transferring them
to a rack to cool completely and what I
like to do while I wait and while these
are still hot is give them a little
extra sprinkling of cinnamon sugar which
may or may not be completely unnecessary
and then like I said after about 5
minutes on the pan we can go ahead and
transfer those onto a cooling rack where
we will let those cool completely before
eating and while I was waiting for that
first batch to cool actually did a
second batch but as a little experiment
I did them without pressing them down I
just left those perfectly round and
carefully transferred those in the oven
and the result of this experiment was
that these came out pretty much exactly
like the first batch maybe just ever so
slightly not quite as flat but anyway
I've always
to be a scientist so that was kind of a
fun experiment and I was always curious
how big a difference it made if you
press them down a little but regardless
either way we are going to let those
cool completely on the rack before
enjoying which for the sake of the video
we will pretend I did and while these
aren't the most spectacular ly beautiful
cookies you'll ever see the taste and
texture more than makes up for it these
are moist tender and chewy in the middle
with just that right amount of crispness
around the edge and then above and
beyond texture that taste is just as
amazing just a beautiful cinnamon a few
sugar cookie that we've elevated with
those warm comforting pumpkin spices and
by the way I just mentioned these aren't
necessarily the most visually beautiful
cookies ever so if you want you can
brush on a simple icing that's just
powdered sugar mixed with a little milk
or lemon juice or apple juice or even
water
I'll have the glaze to the blog but if
you did want to make and brush a little
bit of that glaze over and maybe
sprinkle that a little more of our
cinnamon sugar or just cinnamon and/or
pumpkin spice when that stuff dries that
will give these cookies a little bit of
a shine which some people might think
look better but of course that kind of
thing is going to be up to you you guys
are the Wookiees of your cookies and
speaking of using the force you're gonna
have to force yourself not to eat the
whole pan these are just so delicious
and addictive it's almost not fair but
anyway that's it pumpkin spice
snickerdoodles there was absolutely
nothing wrong with the original
snickerdoodle but much like lattes and
beer before it we added pumpkin spice
anyway except here it made the product
much better so I really do hope you give
these a try soon head over to food
wishes comm for all the ingredient
amounts and more info as usual and as
always enjoy
you
[Music]
